recover.translation[0].definitions[0].de: to get better after an illness, accident, shock etc
recover.translation[0].definitions[0].ex: After a few days of fever, she began to recover.
He’s in hospital, recovering from a heart attack.
recover.translation[0].definitions[0].no: Recover is never transitive in this meaning You say
recover.translation[0].definitions[1].de: to return to a normal condition after a period of trouble or difficulty
recover.translation[0].definitions[1].ex: The tourist industry is recovering to pre-war levels.
Yesterday morning shares seemed to recover from Monday’s collapse.
recover.translation[0].definitions[2].de: to get back something that was taken from you, lost, or almost destroyed
recover.translation[0].definitions[2].ex: Four paintings stolen from the gallery have been recovered.
Two bodies were recovered from the wreckage.
recover.translation[0].definitions[3].de: to get back an amount of money that you have spent or lost
recover.translation[0].definitions[3].ex: He was entitled to recover damages from the defendants.
recover.translation[0].definitions[4].de: to get back an ability, a sense, or control over your feelings, movements etc after a period without it
recover.translation[0].definitions[4].ex: It was some hours before she recovered consciousness.
Once she stumbled, but somehow she recovered her balance and carried on running.
He recovered himself enough to speak calmly.
recover.translation[0].note_box[0].secti: to become healthy again after you have been seriously ill or injured, or had a bad experience
My mother’s been very ill, and she’s still in hospital recovering.
She needed time to recover from the shock.
get better
to recover from an injury or illness. In everyday English, people usually say get better rather than recover
I hope you get better soon.
My back’s been quite bad recently, but it’s getting better slowly.
get over something
to recover from a bad experience, or a minor illness. In everyday English, people usually say get over rather than recover
She never got over his death.
I’m getting over my cold.
get well
to recover from an illness or operation – used especially when you are writing to encourage someone to recover
Get well soon – we all miss you!
I hope you get well quickly.
be back on your feet
to have recovered and be able to live life as usual again
It may take a week or two until you’re back on your feet.
It’s great to see you back on your feet!
be on the mend
to be showing definite signs of recovering after an illness or injury
I’m glad to see you’re on the mend again.
Kathy’s been quite ill with flu, but she seems to be on the mend now.
recuperate
to spend time resting and getting your health or energy back, after you have had an illness or had a difficult or tiring experience
It had been a hard year, and I needed a few weeks in the sun in order to recuperate.
He is recuperating from a heart attack.
convalesce
to spend a long period of time recovering from a serious illness, especially by resting in a comfortable or warm place
She was at home convalescing after major surgery.
recover.translation[1].definitions[0].de: to increase or improve after falling in value or getting worse
recover.translation[1].definitions[0].ex: Its shares plunged at the start of trading, but recovered to close only slightly down.
recover.translation[1].definitions[1].de: to get back money that you have spent or lost
recover.translation[1].definitions[1].ex: The firm sued Mr Yasutomi and has recovered about one-third of its loss.
recover.translation[1].definitions[2].de: to get back something that was stolen, lost, or almost destroyed
recover.translation[1].definitions[2].ex: The FBI recovered over 100 stolen items from his apartment.
recover.translation[1].definitions[3].de: to be paid money by order of a court of law
recover.translation[1].definitions[3].ex: To recover damages against a teacher, a student must be able to show that it was the teacher’s negligence that caused the injury.
recover.translation[1].definitions[4].de: if someone recovers oil, gold etc, they take it from under the ground or sea
recover.translation[1].definitions[4].ex: They plan to recover 35 million barrels of oil from the two fields over six years.
